5. First, upwards in an upright position,
then under and downwards, to the right side
and to the left, receding or going away from us,
then coming the other way, and also around
so that the space is encompassed in a circle. But at all times
one must conform to the enclosure, and keep
the figures from carrying the frame
or looking as if they are stuffed in boxes
left-middleConforming to the size of the panel or canvas.

6. Place the people somewhat loosely, for an agreeable effect.
Do not let your imagination run so wild
and make things so large
that hands and feet run into the frame,
or lie uncomfortably cramped,
so that they are constrained by the space.
Erase and adjust, using the gifts of Art.
Indeed, you are free; do not enslave your figures.
left-middleOne should not make the figures too large, or force them into a small space.

7. Always keep freely within the boundary,
and keep the ground from being too overloaded:
but as you set to work on your invention,
first with careful attention
to your intention, fully consider your meaning
with reading, re-reading; there is no harm in
firmly impressing on your memory
the proper nature of the history.
left-middleFirst read or study [the subject] you wish to paint.

8. First, paint your imagination
with a lively sensitive pieces,
to express your material with pleasing grace
(as good Orators do with their speech)
beautifully, with art and skill.
And in order to better succeed,
You should make some sketches of it,
As many as you need to achieve your power.

9. Let your imagination flow, so that art will bloom.
Like the Italians, you should
draw cartoons from your sketches
